Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, sipping tea, when my granddaughter slid into the chair across from me. Her eyes were wide, uncertain. “Grandpa, how do you know when you’re ready to move out on your own?” she asked, her voice barely above a whisper. I could see she needed more than just a quick answer—she wanted reassurance, wisdom, the kind of guidance only someone who’s lived through it can give. I leaned forward, ready to share my stories and advice, when my phone buzzed urgently. It was a frantic call from my oldest friend, Mark. His car had broken down on the highway, miles from town, and he sounded scared. “Can you come get me? I don’t know who else to call,” he pleaded. My heart twisted. My granddaughter’s hopeful gaze was fixed on me, waiting for comfort, while Mark’s voice echoed in my ear, desperate for help. I felt torn, the weight of both their needs pressing down on me, unsure which role I could bear to let down.
